threats.title: S-F2
threats.description: Attacker forges or steals the mobile appâ€™s credentials/token to call the API as if from the real app
threats.mitigation: Use short-lived OAuth/JWT tokens, validate device or app signatures, monitor for token reuse

threats.title: R-F2
threats.description: An officer denies making certain API calls; the system lacks logs or correlation IDs to prove otherwise.
threats.mitigation: Implement server-side logging with user ID/time stamps for each request, store minimal but sufficient evidence.

threats.title: I-F2
threats.description: Sensitive data (like personal details or DM content) is readable if the connection is leaked or logs are stored plain text.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt all data in transit (HTTPS), sanitize logs, use partial or tokenized data fields.

threats.title: E-F2
threats.description: Hidden API endpoints might be discovered by analyzing the app, letting attackers call privileged routes.
threats.mitigation: Restrict access with role-based checks on the API, separate admin endpoints on a different route or domain.

threats.title: S-F1
threats.description: Attacker impersonates the officer by stealing or guessing device credentials, then launching the mobile app as the legitimate user
threats.mitigation: Strong device passcode policies and short-lived session tokens

threats.title: R-F1
threats.description: Officer or attacker denies having performed certain actions on the mobile device (â€œI never tapped that buttonâ€)
threats.mitigation: local app logs (hashed/timestamped) plus server-side logs correlating device actions with user identity

threats.title: T-F1
threats.description: Malicious actor intercepts or modifies the userâ€™s requests (e.g. text input) on an insecure network before they reach the mobile app.
threats.mitigation: Use end-to-end TLS, verify integrity of requests on the mobile side, encourage officers to avoid untrusted Wi-Fi.

threats.title: I-F1
threats.description: Sensitive data (e.g. session tokens, user info) is exposed if the device or initial app handshake is unencrypted or if logs store raw credentials.
threats.mitigation: Enforce HTTPS/TLS on all connections, mask or encrypt logs, use secure storage for tokens.

threats.title: D-F1
threats.description: Repeated malicious requests from a device overload the app, making it unusable.
threats.mitigation: Implement rate limiting at the local app or server, detect abnormal usage patterns, forced logout.

threats.title: S-F2
threats.description: Attacker forges or steals the mobile appâ€™s credentials/token to call the API as if from the real app
threats.mitigation: Use short-lived OAuth/JWT tokens, validate device or app signatures, monitor for token reuse

threats.title: T-F2
threats.description: The JSON payload and/or route to the API is altered, inserting malicious parameters or removing crucial fields
threats.mitigation: Enforce TLS 1.2 or higher, use request signing/HMAC or schema validation on the API side.

threats.title: R-F2
threats.description: An officer denies making certain API calls; the system lacks logs or correlation IDs to prove otherwise.
threats.mitigation: Implement server-side logging with user ID/time stamps for each request, store minimal but sufficient evidence.

threats.title: I-F2
threats.description: Sensitive data (like personal details or DM content) is readable if the connection is leaked or logs are stored plain text.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt all data in transit (HTTPS), sanitize logs, use partial or tokenized data fields.

threats.title: D-F2
threats.description: Bot or malware repeatedly sends massive requests from the app side, overwhelming the APIâ€™s capacity.
threats.mitigation: Enforce server rate limiting, apply WAF rules, add re-auth or captcha after suspicious volume.
